channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Many Russian Men Flee Moscow in Fear of Draft
item.description: Across the capital, there are noticeably fewer men at restaurants, stores and social gatherings. Many have been called up to fight in Ukraine. Others have fled to avoid being drafted.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

item.title: U.K. Inflation Rises to 10.1 Percent, Driven by Food Prices
item.description: After easing slightly the previous month, inflation continued rising in September, heightening the country’s cost-of-living crisis.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times

item.title: Bread Prices Skyrocket as Inflation Grips Europe
item.description: The elevated costs of flour, nuts, eggs and even electricity are forcing bakers to increase their prices and cut their production.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Violette Franchi for The New York Times

item.title: Consumer Giants Keep Raising Prices as Profits Come Under Pressure
item.description: Nestlé and Procter & Gamble reported resilient earnings as they brought in more money from selling fewer goods.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti
item.media:credit: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters
item.media:description: Procter & Gamble, the owner of Charmin toilet paper and other consumer brands, raised prices by 9 percent in its latest quarter.

item.title: Liz Truss, Jeered in UK Parliament, Insists She Can Govern
item.description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain, who has seen her entire economic agenda repudiated, told lawmakers that she was not a quitter.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Rob Pinney/Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain said she would guarantee a pension increase that her finance chief had called into question.

item.title: Britain Slashes Foreign Aid: ‘You Couldn’t Pick a Worse Time’
item.description: The nation is often the second-largest donor to groups working in poor countries to prevent and treat infectious diseases, and to provide reproductive health services to women.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A shipment of medical supplies, sent from the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office in Britain, arriving in New Delhi last year.

item.title: Waiting for Refugee Status, Thousands Live in Limbo
item.description: As the Biden administration prioritizes resettling people fleeing Ukraine and Afghanistan, many other refugees are waiting years in a system struggling to rebuild.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Feroza Binti Abdul Rashid, a Rohingya refugee, and her 5-year-old daughter at their home in Milwaukee. Her husband has not been able to join the family in the United States.

item.title: Students, Legal Scholars Push California Universities to Hire Undocumented Students
item.description: With a soaring number of immigrant students not eligible to work legally, a new campaign is urging the influential University of California system to employ undocumented students.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Undocumented student leaders from the University of California, Los Angeles, will present a letter to the president of the U.C. system on Wednesday demanding that it put in place a strategy for hiring undocumented students.

item.title: Goodbye Planes, Trains and Automobiles. Hello, Luxury Bus?
item.description: Start-up travel companies are hoping more Americans will embrace the concept of sleeper and luxury coaches. Just don’t call them buses.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.category: Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers on the Napaway coach get comfortable as the bus leaves Washington, D.C., on Oct. 14 for an overnight trip to Nashville.

item.title: As Midterm Campaign Norms Erode, Even Debates Are Under Debate
item.description: Direct political engagement with voters is waning as candidates surround themselves with supporters. “They run these campaigns in bubbles,” a former congressman said.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Ellen Schmidt/Associated Press
item.media:description: A debate in the Nevada governor’s race between Gov. Steve Sisolak, left, and Joe Lombardo, right, was streamed live for $99 before it was broadcast to the public the next day.

item.title: What’s on the Minds of 12 Young Voters
item.description: For these Americans under 30, all living in swing states, political priorities ranged from the highly personal to the universal.
item.media:credit: From left, Nicole Craine for The New York Times, Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times, Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: Suzanne Scott’s Vision for Fox News Gets Tested in Court
item.description: Suzanne Scott remade Fox News Media into a lucrative consumer brand. But a $1.6 billion defamation suit against the company is testing her strategy and leadership.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters and Rachel Abrams

item.title: These Doctors Admit They Don’t Want Patients With Disabilities
item.description: When granted anonymity in focus groups, physicians let their guards down and shared opinions consistent with experiences of many people with disabilities.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lisa Iezzoni, a professor of medicine at Harvard, wanted to understand why people with disabilities kept reporting receiving substandard care. “I thought I needed to start talking to doctors,” she said.

item.title: Weeks After Hurricane Ian, Hundreds of Floridians Remain in Shelters
item.description: Sleeping on cots and air mattresses are newly homeless service-sector employees, low-income retirees and newcomers to the area with few resources or connections.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Reed
item.media:credit: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irene Peralta and Oscar Garcia returned to the Hertz Arena shelter after taking their daughter Janet to a dance rehearsal.

item.title: Is This the World’s Most Picturesque High Dive?
item.description: Catch a glimpse of a storied tradition in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where, for hundreds of years, divers have leaped from a bridge in the southern city of Mostar.
item.dc:creator: Alessio Mamo and Marta Bellingreri

item.title: The Mess in Los Angeles Points to Trouble for Democrats
item.description: The City of Angels is no stranger to zero-sum politics.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images

item.title: Truss and Kwarteng Believed in Markets. Markets Did Not Believe in Them.
item.description: Animated by a fantasy version of the free market, Prime Minister Liz Truss set off a sequence of events that led her to the brink of being ousted by her own party.
item.dc:creator: Quinn Slobodian
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zisiga Mukulu/The New York Times; pool photo by Alastair Grant

item.title: The Midterms Look Very Different if You’re Not a Democrat or a Republican
item.description: “Politically homeless is not politically hopeless.”
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat, Liel Leibovitz and Stephanie Slade
item.media:credit: Illustration by Shoshana Schultz/The New York Times; photographs by Brian Ach and Jeff Swensen via Getty; David Duncan Wallace via The Library of Congress; and Missouri History Museum, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: Natural Disasters Affect Children in Utero. What Can Parents Do?
item.description: Parents shouldn’t freak out. We should push for change.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Eleanor Davis

item.title: Has Polling Broken Politics?
item.description: As the midterms near, Margie Omero and Nate Silver consider what voter surveys are good for.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: A Utah Jury Acquitted Two Animal Rights Activists.
item.description: The acquittal of animal rights activists in Utah suggests attitudes may be changing about factory farming.
item.dc:creator: Wayne Hsiung

item.title: Thank You, Xi Jinping
item.description: China’s paramount leader is restoring faith in the free world — inadvertently, of course.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Mark R Cristino/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: America and China Don’t Need to Knock Each Other Out to Win
item.description: China and the United States should invest more resources in a vision of success not defined by undermining the other.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Chen Weiss
item.media:credit: Lai Qiaoquan/Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Chinese military conducted live-fire military exercises to intimidate Taiwan after a high-profile visit by Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, to Taipei in August.

item.title: The Two Inflation Crises
item.description: Why Europe’s inflation crisis is different from America’s.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oxford Circus in London this year.

item.title: Race, Power and the Leaked Recording in Los Angeles
item.description: A taped conversation between Latino lawmakers has caused a reckoning and raised uncomfortable questions for the city.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Will Reid, Luke Vander Ploeg, Rob Szypko, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Al Seib / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images
item.media:description: Nury Martinez, who was the Los Angeles City Council president, was one of three council members who made racist comments.

item.title: Can China’s leader deliver?
item.description: A party congress appears set to give Xi Jinping five more years in power. He has big goals for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, and big challenges.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping this week at the 20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party.

item.title: We Were Three
item.description: A story of lies, family, America and what Covid revealed, as well as what it destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Updike, Jenelle Pifer, Julie Snyder and Sophie Allison of Soccer Mommy
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: FDA Panel Recommends Pulling Preterm Birth Drug From the Market
item.description: The agency has weighed years of study that showed the treatment given accelerated approval 11 years ago was not effective.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: PeopleImages, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The preterm birth drug Makena has been in use for 11 years, but the F.D.A. recommended withdrawing it from the market. The decision was widely viewed as a test of the agency’s “accelerated approval” program.

item.title: What to Know as Trump Is Deposed in E. Jean Carroll Suit Accusing Him of Rape
item.description: The former president on Wednesday will be asked questions under oath in a defamation case brought by the writer E. Jean Carroll, who says he raped her in a dressing room.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has said his accuser is lying, and has denied harming her.

item.title: Iranian Climber Elnaz Rekabi Is Welcomed by Crowds in Tehran
item.description: Elnaz Rekabi, whose appearance without a head scarf at an event in Seoul raised fears about her future, was welcomed home by crowds in Tehran. Her motivations, and her fate, however, remain unclear.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Rhea Kang/International Federation of Sport Climbing, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Elnaz Rekabi competing at the Asian Championships in Seoul on Sunday, in a photograph provided by the International Federation of Sport Climbing.

item.title: Did Crush Snub Black Fans at a Concert in South Korea?
item.description: The singer Crush apologized for a “misunderstanding” after the exchange, which highlights what experts call K-pop’s uneasy relationship with Black culture.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Yonhap/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The South Korean singer Crush in Seoul in 2018.

item.title: 5 Ways to Prevent Running Injuries This Marathon Season
item.description: Shin splints. Achilles tendinitis. Runner’s knee. Injuries abound for runners, but a sports medicine doctor offers ways to prevent them.
item.dc:creator: Dr. Jordan Metzl

item.title: Balance Exercises to Improve Your Strength
item.description: This simple, often neglected skill can pay huge dividends later in life.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Achauer
item.media:credit: Sarah Karlan for The New York Times

item.title: The Joy Workout
item.description: Six research-backed moves to improve your mood
item.dc:creator: Kelly McGonigal
item.media:credit: na

item.title: A Full-Body Strength Training Workout at Home
item.description: If you’re willing to be creative, a set of elastic bands can be as effective as a gym full of weights.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Marder
item.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: In addition to resistance training, exercise bands can take the edge off of body weight exercises, like pull-ups. But trainers like Vanessa Liu warn against becoming too dependent on them.

item.title: Has Frieze Become an Unofficial Fashion Week?
item.description: With shows from Alexander McQueen, Raf Simons and Roksanda Ilincic, it wasn’t only artists presenting new works in London.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Paton

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
